issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw:
~~Also, I forgot to mention that it doesn't fail if I run the test with gdb.~~

Nevermind, it does fail with gdb, but it matters if there's a zombie gzserver lying around. I'll look at this more tomorrow...
content.html:
Also, I forgot to mention that it doesn't fail if I run the test with gdb.

Nevermind, it does fail with gdb, but it matters if there's a zombie gzserver lying around. I'll look at this more tomorrow...

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw:
This might be a race condition where we're trying to get the address of the remote endpoint before the connection has been established.

Do you have a backtrace?

Here is some [info](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/22425582/remote-endpoint-transport-endpoint-is-not-connected).
content.html:
This might be a race condition where we're trying to get the address of the remote endpoint before the connection has been established.

Do you have a backtrace?

Here is some info.

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw:
If there is an existing gzserver process, then the test passes; otherwise it fails for me. Here's the gdb console output and backtrace for the failure:
~~~
$ gdb tools/UNIT_gz_TEST 
...
(gdb) r
Starting program: build/tools/UNIT_gz_TEST 
[Thread debugging using libthread_db enabled]
Using host libthread_db library "/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libthread_db.so.1".
[New Thread 0x7fffe7492700 (LWP 32342)]
[==========] Running 9 tests from 1 test case.
[----------] Global test environment set-up.
[----------] 9 tests from gzTest
[ RUN      ] gzTest.Alive
[       OK ] gzTest.Alive (148 ms)
[ RUN      ] gzTest.Joint
[New Thread 0x7fffe69c8700 (LWP 32350)]
[Msg] Waiting for master.
[Err] [Connection.cc:787] Getting remote endpoint failed
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::exception_detail::clone_impl<boost::exception_detail::error_info_injector<boost::system::system_error> >'
  what():  remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

Program received signal SIGABRT, Aborted.
[Switching to Thread 0x7fffe69c8700 (LWP 32350)]
0x00007ffff5c41f79 in __GI_raise (sig=sig@entry=6) at ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/raise.c:56
56	../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/raise.c: No such file or directory.
~~~

content.html:
If there is an existing gzserver process, then the test passes; otherwise it fails for me. Here's the gdb console output and backtrace for the failure:

$ gdb tools/UNIT_gz_TEST 
...
(gdb) r
Starting program: build/tools/UNIT_gz_TEST 
[Thread debugging using libthread_db enabled]
Using host libthread_db library "/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libthread_db.so.1".

[==========] Running 9 tests from 1 test case.
[----------] Global test environment set-up.
[----------] 9 tests from gzTest
[ RUN      ] gzTest.Alive
[       OK ] gzTest.Alive (148 ms)
[ RUN      ] gzTest.Joint
[New Thread 0x7fffe69c8700 (LWP 32350)]
[Msg] Waiting for master.
[Err] [Connection.cc:787] Getting remote endpoint failed
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::exception_detail::clone_impl<boost::exception_detail::error_info_injector<boost::system::system_error> >'

Program received signal SIGABRT, Aborted.

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw:
I printed out the boost error code at Connection.cc:787 and it appears to be `system:107`. From errno.h:
~~~
$ grep 107 /usr/include/asm-generic/errno.h 
#define	ENOTCONN	107	/* Transport endpoint is not connected */
~~~
Doesn't seem to add any new information.
content.html:
I printed out the boost error code at Connection.cc:787 and it appears to be system:107. From errno.h:

$ grep 107 /usr/include/asm-generic/errno.h 
#define ENOTCONN    107 /* Transport endpoint is not connected */

Doesn't seem to add any new information.

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw:
The backtrace implicated `Connection::OnConnect`, and I noticed that it references `socket->remote_endpoint()` in a different way than the `Connection::GetRemoteEndpoint()` function. I changed it to use the `GetRemoteEndpoint()` function with the following:
~~~
diff -r 0c1dd36ccb70 gazebo/transport/Connection.cc
--- a/gazebo/transport/Connection.cc	Tue Jun 10 14:37:23 2014 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/transport/Connection.cc	Tue Jun 10 16:02:01 2014 -0700
@@ -846,7 +846,7 @@
     if (this->socket && this->socket->is_open())
     {
       this->remoteAddress =
-        this->socket->remote_endpoint().address().to_string();
+        this->GetRemoteEndpoint().address().to_string();
     }
     else
     {
~~~

This causes the test to generate a bunch of console messages and eventually hang:
~~~
$ tools/UNIT_gz_TEST 
[==========] Running 9 tests from 1 test case.
[----------] Global test environment set-up.
[----------] 9 tests from gzTest
[ RUN      ] gzTest.Alive
[       OK ] gzTest.Alive (130 ms)
[ RUN      ] gzTest.Joint
[Msg] Waiting for master.
[Err] [Connection.cc:787] Getting remote endpoint failed
[Err] [Connection.cc:787] Getting remote endpoint failed
[Err] [Connection.cc:516] Connection[0] Closed during Read
[Err] [ConnectionManager.cc:134] Unable to read from master
/home/scpeters/ws/gazebo/src/gazebo/tools/gz_TEST.cc:108: Failure
Value of: gazebo::transport::init()
  Actual: false
Expected: true
[Err] [ConnectionManager.cc:552] Not initialized
[Err] [ConnectionManager.cc:552] Not initialized
[Err] [ConnectionManager.cc:552] Not initialized
[Err] [ConnectionManager.cc:552] Not initialized
[Err] [ConnectionManager.cc:552] Not initialized
[Err] [ConnectionManager.cc:552] Not initialized
[Err] [ConnectionManager.cc:552] Not initialized
[Err] [ConnectionManager.cc:552] Not initialized
[Err] [ConnectionManager.cc:552] Not initialized
[Err] [ConnectionManager.cc:552] Not initialized
[Err] [ConnectionManager.cc:552] Not initialized
[Err] [Node.cc:98] No namespace found
[Err] [ConnectionManager.cc:598] ConnectionManager is not initialized
^C^C
~~~
content.html:
The backtrace implicated Connection::OnConnect, and I noticed that it references socket->remote_endpoint() in a different way than the Connection::GetRemoteEndpoint() function. I changed it to use the GetRemoteEndpoint() function with the following:

diff -r 0c1dd36ccb70 gazebo/transport/Connection.cc
--- a/gazebo/transport/Connection.cc    Tue Jun 10 14:37:23 2014 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/transport/Connection.cc    Tue Jun 10 16:02:01 2014 -0700
@@ -846,7 +846,7 @@
     if (this->socket && this->socket->is_open())
     {
       this->remoteAddress =
-        this->socket->remote_endpoint().address().to_string();
+        this->GetRemoteEndpoint().address().to_string();
     }
     else
     {

This causes the test to generate a bunch of console messages and eventually hang:

$ tools/UNIT_gz_TEST 
[==========] Running 9 tests from 1 test case.
[----------] Global test environment set-up.
[----------] 9 tests from gzTest

/home/scpeters/ws/gazebo/src/gazebo/tools/gz_TEST.cc:108: Failure

Expected: true

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw:
We experienced the same issue when launching `gazebo` with a system plugin compiled in `Debug` mode (Gazebo version 3.0 from debian packages, Ubuntu 14.04).
The issue did not arise when using the same system plugin compiled in `Release` mode. 

If someone has the same problem he may be interested in a workaround. We launched `gzserver` (with the system plugin compiled in `Debug`) and after we launched `gzclient` in a separate terminal. In this way we were able to have a working simulation, I guess avoiding the `gzserver`-`gzclient` race condition.
content.html:
We experienced the same issue when launching gazebo with a system plugin compiled in Debug mode (Gazebo version 3.0 from debian packages, Ubuntu 14.04). The issue did not arise when using the same system plugin compiled in Release mode.

If someone has the same problem he may be interested in a workaround. We launched gzserver (with the system plugin compiled in Debug) and after we launched gzclient in a separate terminal. In this way we were able to have a working simulation, I guess avoiding the gzserver-gzclient race condition.

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw:
Good point @traversaro , an even simpler way to replicate this error is to launch `gzclient` or run `gz stats` without a `gzserver` running on the system.

@nkoenig @caguero should these processes fail like this or are they expected to wait for a server to come up?
content.html:
Good point @traversaro , an even simpler way to replicate this error is to launch gzclient or run gz stats without a gzserver running on the system.

@nkoenig @caguero should these processes fail like this or are they expected to wait for a server to come up?

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw:
It seems that this could possibly be caused by https://svn.boost.org/trac/boost/ticket/8795

Basically, the async_connect seems indicate a successful connection even when it failed. That issue was in boost 1.54 (the version on trusty), and it looks like a fix was found 8 months ago, but maybe it hasn't been released?
content.html:
It seems that this could possibly be caused by https://svn.boost.org/trac/boost/ticket/8795

Basically, the async_connect seems indicate a successful connection even when it failed. That issue was in boost 1.54 (the version on trusty), and it looks like a fix was found 8 months ago, but maybe it hasn't been released?

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw:
@jbinney Thanks for finding that! Is sounds like a bug with boost 1.54 only. That bug is [known in ubuntu](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/boost-defaults/+bug/1319338). @\_jrivero_ what do you think is the likelihood of this being patched in ubuntu?

If an ubuntu patch is unlikely, we should consider making a workaround for systems using boost 1.54.
content.html:
@jbinney Thanks for finding that! Is sounds like a bug with boost 1.54 only. That bug is known in ubuntu. @_jrivero_ what do you think is the likelihood of this being patched in ubuntu?

If an ubuntu patch is unlikely, we should consider making a workaround for systems using boost 1.54.

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw: Even if the boost bug is fixed, isn't there an (admittedly unlikely) race condition? The connection could be create successfully, OnConnect could be called, and the server could die right at that moment. OnConnect seems to assume that if "_error" is zero upon entering the function, that the connection does not die during the call. Maybe it is a good idea to handle errors from GetRemoteEndpoint anyway?
content.html: Even if the boost bug is fixed, isn't there an (admittedly unlikely) race condition? The connection could be create successfully, OnConnect could be called, and the server could die right at that moment. OnConnect seems to assume that if "_error" is zero upon entering the function, that the connection does not die during the call. Maybe it is a good idea to handle errors from GetRemoteEndpoint anyway?

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw: It looks like [libboost1.54-dev](http://packages.ubuntu.com/eo/trusty/i386/libboost1.54-dev) is the package that provides the suspect boost asio headers.
content.html: It looks like libboost1.54-dev is the package that provides the suspect boost asio headers.

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.html:
//cc @tfoote

@scpeters is clearly a regression, there is an example of making it to fail, the patch is small and does not impact the ABI, so I see no reason why not to fix it ASAP. One option is to build our own version of libboost1.54-dev and host it in the OSRF repository, but this comes with the risk of breaking things heavily.

I would recommend that everyone vote on the issue and see if we need a new bug or we can push from there in order to get the patch uploaded. If we don't have any news for the following days, I would go with the patched version into OSRF repository.

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw: I'm always hesitant to bring in other packages into our repositories with patches as it just adds to our maintenance load. However I doubt that our flagging the bug will get it fixed very quickly so we should probably prepare a patched version for testing and possible release ourselves.
content.html: I'm always hesitant to bring in other packages into our repositories with patches as it just adds to our maintenance load. However I doubt that our flagging the bug will get it fixed very quickly so we should probably prepare a patched version for testing and possible release ourselves.

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw: I was able to make a Debug compilation pass the UNIT_gz_TEST and not display that message after patching the local boost header using [the patch in the boost issue tracker](https://svn.boost.org/trac/boost/changeset/85738). Could someone please give it a try and confirm this? If so, I will send the ubuntu the proper patches to speed up the process.
content.html: I was able to make a Debug compilation pass the UNIT_gz_TEST and not display that message after patching the local boost header using the patch in the boost issue tracker. Could someone please give it a try and confirm this? If so, I will send the ubuntu the proper patches to speed up the process.

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw:
@\_jrivero_ that patch worked for me (modified boost/asio/detail/impl/socket_ops.ipp). I tested it by running the UNIT_gz_TEST, which passes when compiled against that header. Another test is to run `gzclient --verbose` and you should see `[Msg] Waiting for master.` without the remote endpoint failed message.

Since it is a header file change, we'll have to rebuild the gazebo debs against the new version.
content.html:
@_jrivero_ that patch worked for me (modified boost/asio/detail/impl/socket_ops.ipp). I tested it by running the UNIT_gz_TEST, which passes when compiled against that header. Another test is to run gzclient --verbose and you should see [Msg] Waiting for master. without the remote endpoint failed message.

Since it is a header file change, we'll have to rebuild the gazebo debs against the new version.

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw: I've sent a small test and a debdiff patch to the [Ubuntu bug](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/boost-defaults/+bug/1319338). This should speed up things for the SRU bugs affecting Trusty. If it is not fixed during the weekend, we can build and host our modified copy of libboost asio, although I would prefer have it fixed directly in Ubuntu.
content.html: I've sent a small test and a debdiff patch to the Ubuntu bug. This should speed up things for the SRU bugs affecting Trusty. If it is not fixed during the weekend, we can build and host our modified copy of libboost asio, although I would prefer have it fixed directly in Ubuntu.

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw: Amazing Ubuntu fast response. Could you all please try to install the [proposed boost-1.54 package](http://launchpadlibrarian.net/178088918/libboost1.54-dev_1.54.0-4ubuntu3.1_amd64.deb) and see if it fixes the problem for you? For extra points, comment on the [Ubuntu bug](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/boost-defaults/+bug/1319338) is also desired.
content.html: Amazing Ubuntu fast response. Could you all please try to install the proposed boost-1.54 package and see if it fixes the problem for you? For extra points, comment on the Ubuntu bug is also desired.

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw:
I tested on my machine (Gazebo compiled from `default` branch) and using the proposed package solves the problem, both the one with the yarp specific system plugin [I mentioned before](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1204/trusty-remote_endpoint-transport-endpoint#comment-10659464) and the one that occurs when launching `gzclient --verbose` without any server running. 

By the way, on the Ubuntu bug they link a proposed `boost-mpi` package, I guess it is just an error, right?
content.html:
I tested on my machine (Gazebo compiled from default branch) and using the proposed package solves the problem, both the one with the yarp specific system plugin I mentioned before and the one that occurs when launching gzclient --verbose without any server running.

By the way, on the Ubuntu bug they link a proposed boost-mpi package, I guess it is just an error, right?

content.raw:
Thanks very much for the testing Silvio. I would say that we could be facing different bugs with respect to the yarp specific system plugin and the gzclient alone. Maybe we can open a couple of different issues to handle them and get the gdb traces for each one and any related information using this good boost package?

The ubuntu bug links to changes in boost-mpi but if you read a bit above (comment #9) there is also the link to just boost. Two versions are maintained.

content.raw: Brian, we need to rebuild gazebo2 and gazebo3 with the new boost in order to get the fixes into gazebo packages, since the patch lives in a boost header. It won't be enough to install the package, as usual in the others libraries. I'm working on this new release and will update and close this issue when new versions are released.
content.html: Brian, we need to rebuild gazebo2 and gazebo3 with the new boost in order to get the fixes into gazebo packages, since the patch lives in a boost header. It won't be enough to install the package, as usual in the others libraries. I'm working on this new release and will update and close this issue when new versions are released.

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw:
The deb on the OSRF repository doesn't seem to be working right for me. 

There are two issues that I can see so far. My old gazebo seems to have been in /usr/local/bin and the new deb installed in /usr/bin. `which gazebo` reports the old debs (which look like 2.2.1).   

Running the right executable gives me linking errors 
`./gzclient: symbol lookup error: ./gzclient: undefined symbol: _ZN6gazebo12printVersionEv`
but that might be a related issue.

I also have ros indigo and gazebo_ros installed on this machine if that's an issue.

Running the right executable gives me linking errors ./gzclient: symbol lookup error: ./gzclient: undefined symbol: _ZN6gazebo12printVersionEv but that might be a related issue.

issue.title: Trusty: remote_endpoint: Transport endpoint is not connected

content.raw: Into /usr/local you should only have from build installation, packages should always go to /usr. Please be sure that you remove all previous compilations (cd gazebo/build && make uninstall) so you won't have anything related to gazebo in /usr/local.
content.html: Into /usr/local you should only have from build installation, packages should always go to /usr. Please be sure that you remove all previous compilations (cd gazebo/build && make uninstall) so you won't have anything related to gazebo in /usr/local.
